titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went to the play, to see Voltaire’s Semiramis. But found the house so full that I could not get a seat any where. Returned home, intending to pass the Evening after the manner the most conformable to my inclination; but in sitting down to fill up the arrears of my Diary, recollected, what I had forgotten nearly a week that I was engaged at Madam Cneiff’s.— Went accordingly and found a considerable party. Play’d Reversi.— Mr: Levsen told me upon enquiry, that by the usage of the Country a formal visit must be paid both to Mr: Noël, and to his future Lady in return for his notifications— Changed my apartment this morning for my summer residence.

2. Called on Mr: Levsen this morning and took a walk with him to Scheveling. Went into the church where we found the Minister preaching to a large and very decent auditory.— Dined at M: de Schubart’s.— Mr: Herselen & his daughter.— Sir Robert Barclay, who talked of Eustace. He is at Rotterdam. Visit this forenoon to Mr: Noël, and this Evening to Mlle: Bogaert.— Neither at home.— Evening at My lodgings reading Necker’s tale of misery upon the french Revolution.

3. A day at my own disposal. Finished Lord Kames’s Elements of Criticism. This was a second reading; they did not please me so much as at the first. His style is harsh, and unconnected; and his ideas often obscure; often too refined: sometimes unfounded. The want of method is an essential defect. He is however ingenious; and the freedom with which he censures all the most eminent writers antient and modern when they depart from his principles of taste may have its utility.— Took up Locke’s Essay on the Understanding.— And continued the perusal of Necker’s book.

4. Dined at Mr: Van Leyden’s. Company not numerous. General Daendels talked about Eustace. Thinks he would do well to go home. Says Jacob Van Staphorst himself told him that Eustace was employed to come here and consult measures with the Patriots at the time of the french invasion; and that he did not acquit himself well of the commission.— Came home and found a Letter from General Pinckney with the Newspapers.— Reading them detained me till I was late at Madam Cneiff’s.— Evening dull as usual.
5. Bielfeld called on me this morning. Walk with him to Scheveling.— Evening at Count Löwenhielm’s. Mr: de Martilli told us an anecdote about the Duke of Orleans and the Comte de Limon.

6. Letter from the Secretary of state forwarded to me from Mr: Pinckney at Amsterdam. Walk in the wood. Beginning of the Evening at Madam May’s.— Remainder of it at Mr: Noël’s.— Quadrill with Mlles: Bicker and De Milly and Mr: Levsen.
7. Passed the forenoon in writing and the time for walking slipped away.— Reading Locke, which is yet a labour.— An hour in the Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.— Music.—

8. Walking this forenoon towards Ryswick, met Mr: Levsen— He walk’d with me. On our return visited the books that are to be sold next week.— Evening at home, by refusing a party. Should perhaps have done as well to accept it.

9. Received this morning from Mr: Williams the Consul at Hamburg a letter with a Packet from the Secretary of State, containing my recall from the mission here, and a Commission as Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States to Portugal, and also a couple of Letters, one of them containing instructions for my new mission.— Wrote some Letters. Evening at home. Called on Mr: Van Staphorst.
10. Weather cold and unpleasant. Dined at Count Löwenhielm’s. Party not large.— Evening at Madam May’s. Attended the sale of books.— Reflecting upon the necessary preparations for my departure.

11. At the sale.— Walk with Mr: Levsen.— Visited the ruins of the Monastery on the road to Loosduynen.— Burying ground— Relics of mortality— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.— Began this morning to translate the Annals of Tacitus. Finished the Histories, yesterday.

12. Sale.— Called on Mr: Van Leyden. He was not at home.— Walk with Mr: Levsen to Scheveling. Went up to the top of the tour of the Church.— The Sexton told us that in the year 1570. there was an inundation which destroyed 148 houses beyond the Church towards the Sea. There were five feet of water in the Church itself.— We saw below a picture of Scheveling before that disaster. The greatest part of the village was beyond the Church— At present there are only two or three houses a little beyond it on the other side of the Street. About four years ago the Sea, gained 95 feet upon the shore, but has since returned to its preceding State, as it has been for more than two centuries.— Evening at Count Lowenhielm’s.— Cards.
13. Walk in the wood. Met Bielfeld with my brother.— Mr: Noël’s weekly parties cease— At the sale, and made some purchases.— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.
14. Endeavouring to make Preparations for my departure. Busily engaged— My brother preparing to go to Paris.
15. Bielfeld called on me this afternoon. Evening at Madam May’s.— Played Whist. Find my employments degenerating to idleness. Captain Cunningham here.
16. Mr: König here this forenoon. My brother set out for Paris. I know not how the time passes.— Evening at home, reading.

17. Endeavoured this morning to see Mr: Van Leyden. Was too late.— Mr: Cutting, Mr: Shaw, Mr: Apthorp called here; the former with a letter of introduction from my brother Charles.— Packing up my books.

18. Mr: Cutting and his friends disappointed in their design of going to Paris. Mr: Noël under a decree of the Directory, things himself obliged to refuse certifying their Passports.— Went with them to the house in the wood, and to Scheveling. They dined with me.— General Pinckney called on me this afternoon, with Mr: Horry, and Major Rutledge.— Evening at Mr: Bosset’s. Large Party.

19. Visited this forenoon, General Pinckney at the Keyzershoff. Mr: Cutting and his friends called to take leave and are going on to Rotterdam.— Called on Mr: Van Leyden for the third time and found him at length at home.— Conversation with him. Captain Mackay likewise called to see me.— Evening at Count Löwenhielm’s.

20. Called again to see General Pinckney, this morning. Mr: Rutgers was here, and proceeded to Amsterdam. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Find myself excessively overbusied, with nothing to do. Every species of anxiety bears upon me at once.

21. Still packing up my books, and writing Letters.— Evening at Madam Schimmelpenninck’s, large party. Mr: Horry called here in the afternoon.— Bielfeld.— Supper at Madam Schimmelpenninck’s; and late home.

22. Broke through for the first time my morning labours. The progressive influence of Indolence is irresistible— Video, meliora, proboque.— Find myself it is true, somewhat unwell.— Met Major Rutledge towards Evening and walked with him. Upon coming home found a packet from England.— A number of Pamphlets.

23. The broken ice is not like to be repaired. Major Rutledge called on me this forenoon. Walked with him to Scheveling. Found General Pinckney and his Lady, and Mr: Horry there. Afternoon and Evening, writing, at home.

24. Called on General Pinckney again this forenoon. He read me an account of his nonreception at Paris, and of his being afterwards ordered away.— Agreed upon going tomorrow to Leyden.— Evening at the Baron de Schubart’s. Very large party. Reversi with Madam d’Anduaga, Madam de Lange, and General Rewbell.

25. Went with General Pinckney and his family to Leyden, in the Schuyt. Called on Mr: Luzac. After dinner he came, and attended us to see the Anatomical museum and the Library. The Latter I had never seen before. The collection is large and valuable but they have not room enough for the books.— There are number of antient manuscripts of the Classics. Among the rest an Homer more than 900 years old as they say. I enquired after the Agricola manuscript of Tacitus which was owned by Ryckius, when he published his Edition of that author, being then a professor at this University, but I could not find that they knew any thing of it. Mr: Luzac passed an hour with us towards Evening.
26. We returned to the Hague, by the Schuit in the forenoon. Found some letters upon my arrival. In the Evening called at Mr: Veerman’s.— Found Madam Van Staphorst and Mlle: Cazeau there.
27. Attended at the sale of books and made a few purchases.— Called on General Pinckney and attended him, and Mr: Horry to the National Assembly. Evening at Madam Cneiff’s.
28. At the sale again. Evening at Count Löwenhielm’s. A very large party. Cards as usual. Madame de Lange. Mlle: Bicker and Bielfeld.
29. Sale concluded. Walk towards Delft.— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Reading over many of the Papers relative to American affairs of the late Mr: Dumas. Madam V. is to send them to me.

Day. Relapsing almost entirely into Indolence, and I cannot help it. Up at 8 in the morning. Forenoon writing or reading. Afternoon read again a little, and Evening usually in company. My only excuse (a poor one) is that I am on the wing.

30. Dined at Count Lowenhielm’s.— Small party. The Count de Rechteren. Evening at Madam Cneiff’s.— Cards with Madam Schimmelpenninck, Mr: Van der Hoop and Bielfeld.— Called in the morning on General Pinckney.
